ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class taught me to think analytically about contemporary Indigenous issues across the globe, and to discern commonalities and differences. I also learned how to incorporate art into my academic study, which provided me with critical and creative thinking skills I have not received from other courses.

I gained knowledge about the experiences, works, and insights of Indigenous communities and individuals throughout the world, as well as resources to continue to engage with and learn from Indigenous creators.

I learned so much about different Indigenous cultures around the world, including their histories, their art, elements of their culture. I have not learned more in the field of Native studies in years, and this was such an informative and fascinating class

I developed an ability to seriously and respectfully engage with Indigenous cultural and social movements from a variety of regional focuses throughout the world. This general survey course, although perhaps not incredibly specific by its nature, allowed me to flexibly and meaningfully introduce these movements into an academic space.

This course allowed me to reconsider my personal concept of Indigeneity. Throughout the course, we investigated the complex histories involving Indigenous people from around the world. The global context aspect truly illuminated the ways in which the US education system lacks an understanding of Indigenous peoples.
Learned about indigenous people all over the world and how they interact with the non-indigenous society around them. I was exposed to a wonderful variety of culture, design, music, and language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The variety of materials covered in this course meant that I was never overwhelmed by the content. The assignments were all interesting and aided my understanding of the concepts in different ways. Class discussions were always insightful and respectful.

Strengths: Professor Onco-Ingyadet is intentional in every selection of readings, listenings and multimedia materials. Her syllabus is life-affirming and her instruction is patient and generous. We had engaging guest lectures and flexible assignments that truly helped accommodate pandemic learning.

This class had a lot of content for each class, which was once a week, but much of it wasn't readings, but music and art and website to fully learn more about the culture, which was wonderful. The assignments allowed for a lot of creativity and engagement with the work and Indigeneity in general. It was a wonderful class

The biggest weakness of this course was the sheer breadth that it attempted to cover, coupled with the limited amount of time we had to thoroughly delve into each regional focus. It sometimes felt as if we weren't able to do each region complete justice, despite our best intentions as students and faculty, as a result of the time constraints we had to work with. That said, I believe that, in spite of the ambition of the course, Prof. Onco-Ingyadet managed to make the course incredibly accessible and easy to approach. Her commitment to highlighting alternative sources for learning and legitimizing them through our own academic engagement is commendable, and she clearly cares deeply and personally about the subject matter being taught. In many ways, her encouragement allowed us to begin building connections between the various sources we encountered. That said, I think narrowing in on the focus of the course would serve it well in the future, to make sure that we don't sacrifice too much depth in our commitment to breadth.

Weakness - the course only needed one assignment to serve as a final assignment. Either the Expressions or Final paper. 

Strengths - the speakers incorporated into the syllabus, a highly motivated instructor, engaging course material.
This course was very strong. Its use of multiple forms of media to teach was refreshing and wonderfully efficient.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course and Instructor adapted well to the constraints of the pandemic. Weekly emails helped me stay on track with the course.

The presentation portion of the classes were recorded, which was very helpful for remembering what the professor had said about the class materials and assignments. The class worked well in a virtual context.

This was the first time with the class, so it was engaging online, she made sure to take breaks and make sure we weren't overwhelmed, even giving us time off as necessary for mental health which was wonderful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to other students because I received an education that has been lacking in my four years at Yale. This is one of the first courses taught by Indigenous person about Indigenous issues across the globe, which is a total rejection of regional bias. I think every student should have to engage in a course like this, especially as it reorients students to consider contemporary Indigenous people and their communities' historical struggle, as juxtaposed to only historicizing Indigenous people.
I would absolutely recommend this course.
Yes, 100%. Professor Onco-Ingyadet was incredible and there is no class like this one at Yale. It felt like a diamond when I first enrolled in it, and it definitely was by the the end.

Absolutely! As this course continues to be taught it will only grow and improve. This is a unique and powerful space to learn about contemporary Indigenous peoples not as an afterthoughts, but as the primary subject of scholarship.

I cannot recommend this class enough! It was my favorite class I've taken at Yale so far, and I'm halfway through an an ERM major. I learned so much, I loved all of the media and readings we read, the assignments were well thought out and I was so proud of what I wrote, the class community was wonderful, it was a truly amazing class

I would absolutely be happy to recommend this course to any student interested in engaging with Indigenous forms of knowledge seriously throughout the world, especially in a contemporary context that seems bent on relegating these knowledge systems to the past.
Yes! Any student studying Indigenous people must take this course. It creates a foundation of learning that will benefit them longer after their time at Yale.
Absolutely! I would recommend this course to anyone at Yale, those who want to learn about indigenous people and cultures will not be disappointed!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Guest lectures conducted on Zoom.
it was a virtual seminar, with a bit of a lecture piece, but not much
